awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  CO2 hydrate production for large-scale CO2 sequestration
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of technology to sequester carbon dioxide (CO2) as CO2 hydrates. CO2 hydrates are ice-like solids, consisting of CO2 and water. Stable CO2 hydrates form at ~0 ̊C, and at moderate pressures (~450 psi) from a mixture of CO2 and water. CO2 hydrates can be safely sequestered long-term via multiple options (under seabed, under permafrost, depleted gas fields). This I-Corps project targets eventual commercialization of CO2 hydrates-based carbon capture and sequestration (CCS). Many commercialization partners exist among process industries, oil-gas industry, and utilities. A likely post-project scenario involves establishing a startup company as the commercialization vehicle (which develops sector-specific CCS solutions). Successful commercialization may lead to significant employment opportunities, and contribute to positioning the US as a leader in this field. Most importantly, it will augment the portfolio of technological and geoengineering solutions to tackle climate change. This project also will stimulate other applications of gas hydrates including desalination, gas separation and hydrogen storage.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology to rapidly form CO2 hydrates from a mixture of CO2 and water. Key technological challenges underlying artificial synthesis of hydrates have been very slow growth rates, and low conversion rates of gas to hydrates. State of the art technology to speed up hydrate formation includes the use of chemical promoters, which are expensive and environmentally friendly. The team at UT Austin has made several scientific discoveries and developed multiple novel approaches to speed up growth of hydrates, which may cumulatively speed up hydrate formation by an order of magnitude faster than state-of-the-art. Specific novel advancements integrated in the proposed technology include recently discovered hydrate nucleation promoters, a technique to enhance gas-liquid interfacial area and convection, and the use of high thermal conductivity materials to speed up heat transfer. Cumulatively, these advancements may enable rapid, on-demand CO2 hydrate production without the use of chemical promoters. The intellectual merit of this project lies in the integration of multiple fundamental advancements to realize rapid hydrate formation in reactor configurations commonly used by the chemicals processing industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Success of gigascale carbon capture and sequestration depends on safe, long-term storage of carbon dioxide (CO2) in all regions of the planet. This project is about customer discovery and assessment of commercial prospects of a novel technology concept for gigascale carbon sequestration, developed at The University of Texas at Austin. This involves carbon storage on the seabed in the form of sealed CO2 hydrates. CO2 hydrates are ice-like crystalline materials formed from CO2 and water under medium-pressure (~500 psi), low temperature conditions, which are common at the seabed in most regions of the planet. 1 kg of solid CO2 hydrate can sequester upto 290 grams of CO2 (i.e. 150 liters of CO2 at 25 ̊C & 1 atm).

Intellectual Merit:

Via interviews with 100+ professionals in the carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) industry, the team learned that this technology is an attractive alternative to the current practice for sequestration which is reservoir injection of CO2. Injection has a lot of limitations/challenges including: i) lack of suitable geology to sequester CO2 in many regions (China, India, Japan, Korea etc.) ii) Risk of leaks and seismicity, iii) requirements of high-purity (> 95%) CO2. iv) Significant area footprint of injection projects (> 100 sq. km for a 1 Megaton CO2/yr project). In contrast the key benefits of hydrates-based seabed storage include: i) vast storage sites, ii) stable p, T conditions, iii) 100X smaller area footprint than injection projects, iv) low seismic and leak risks and v) compatibility with low-purity CO2 streams.

Key challenges associated with this technology include: i) rapid formation of CO2 hydrates, ii) sealing CO2 hydrates to prevent dissociation on seabed, iii) realizing 2-3X cost reduction to achieve parity with state-of-art practice of reservoir injection. THe research group at UT Austin has successfully addressed the first challenge of rapidly forming CO2 hydrates. Via a combination of promotion techniques (multiple patents pending), the group has achieved a 6X enhancement in the rate at which hydrates can be produced artificially. Our technology enables the sequestration of 10+ tons of CO2 annually using a reactor having the size of a soda can. Importantly, we do not use any chemical promoters, which has significant advantages from an EHS standpoint. Remaining challenges (sealing, costs) to adoption of this technology can be addressed by fundamental/applied R&D and by scaling.

Borader impacts:

Overall, this technology is a very promising alternative to the current practice for CO2 storage. Further R&D can position it for adoption at scale in the early 2030’s.  Participation in the NSF I-Corps program indicated significant commercial interest in this technology. The findings of this project can be translated to real world applications via a startup that can engage with the energy industry. This will also lead to significant economic activity and employment generation. This project also led to entrepreneurial training opportunities for 2 PhD students at UT Austin.

 


Last Modified: 04/09/2024
Modified by: Vaibhav Bahadur
